contextId.information: Paul speaks of Christ's sufferings as if they were objects that could increase in number. AT: "For just as Christ suffered greatly for our sake"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For just as the sufferings of Christ abound for our sake

contextId.information: Paul speaks of comfort as if it were an object that could increase in size. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: our comfort abounds

contextId.information: Paul compares his feeling of despair as a result of the troubles that they experienced to a deadly peril or terrible danger. AT: "despair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a deadly peril

contextId.information: This means that God has marked believers as his own possession. AT: "He marked us as his own possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He set his seal on us

contextId.information: The Spirit is spoken of as if he was a partial downpayment toward eternal life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Spirit ... as a guarantee

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his opportunity to preach the gospel as if it were a door through which he was allowed to walk. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Lord opened a door to me ... to preach the gospel" or "The Lord gave me the opportunity ... to preach the gospel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: A door was opened to me by the Lord ... to preach the gospel

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God as if he were a victorious general leading a victory parade and of himself and his coworkers as those who take part in that parade. Possible meanings are 1) "God, who in Christ always causes us to share in his triumph" or 2) "God, who in Christ always leads us in triumph as those over whom he as gained victory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God, who in Christ always leads us in triumph

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his ministry as if it were a burnt offering that someone offers to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: we are to God the sweet aroma of Christ

contextId.information: "the knowledge of Christ is an aroma." This refers back to [[:en:bible:notes:2co:02:14|2:14]], where Paul speaks of the knowledge of Christ as if it were incense that has a pleasing smell. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: it is an aroma

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the Corinthians as if they are a letter of recommendation. That they have become believers serves to validate Paul's ministry to others. AT: "You yourselves are like our letter of recommendation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You yourselves are our letter of recommendation

contextId.information: Paul clarifies that Christ is the one who has written the letter. AT: "you are a letter that Christ has written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: you are a letter from Christ

contextId.information: Paul speaks of "the service of righteousness" as if it were an object that could produce or multiply another object. He means that "the service of righteousness" is far more glorious than the law, which also had glory. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the service of righteousness abound in glory

contextId.information: This refers to "the service of condemnation," which Paul speaks of as if it were an object capable of disappearing. AT: "that which was becoming useless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that which was passing away

contextId.information: "But their minds were hardened." Paul speaks of the minds of the Israelite people as objects that could be closed or made hard. This expression means that they were unable to understand what they saw. AT: "But the Israelites could not understand what they saw" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But their minds were closed

contextId.information: Just as the Israelites could not see the glory on Moses' face because he covered his face with a veil, there is a spiritual veil that prevents people from understanding when they read the old covenant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the same veil remains on the reading of the old covenant

contextId.information: Unlike the Israelites who could not see God's glory reflected on Moses' face because he had covered it with a veil, there is nothing to prevent believers from seeing and understanding God's glory. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with unveiled faces, see the glory of the Lord

contextId.information: This refers to God's presence. God's understanding and approval of Paul's truthfulness is referred to as God being able to see them. AT: "before God" or "with God as witness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the sight of God

contextId.information: This refers back to [[:en:bible:notes:2co:03:14|3:14-16]], where Paul explained that there is a spiritual veil that prevents people from understanding when they read the old covenant. In the same way, people are not able to understand the gospel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But if our gospel is veiled, it is veiled only to those who are perishing

contextId.information: Paul speaks of their minds as if they had eyes, and their inability to understand as their minds being unable to see. AT: "the god of this world has prevented unbelievers from understanding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the god of this world has blinded their unbelieving minds

contextId.information: As the Israelites could not see God's glory that shined on Moses' face because he covered it with a veil (see [[:en:bible:notes:2co:03:12|3:13]]), unbelievers are not able to see Christ's glory that shines in the gospel. This means that they are unable to understand "the gospel of the glory of Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are not able to see the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ

contextId.information: Here the word "light" refers to the ability to understand. Just as God created light, he also creates understanding for believers. AT: "He has shone ... to enable us to understand the glory of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has shone ... to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God

contextId.information: "the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ." Just as God's glory shone upon Moses' face (see [[:en:bible:notes:2co:03:07|3:7]]), it also shines upon Jesus face. This means that when Paul preaches the gospel, people are able to see and understand the message about God's glory. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the glory of God in the presence of Jesus Christ

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the gospel as if it were a treasure and their bodies as if they were breakable jars made out of clay. This emphasizes that they are of little value compared to the worth of the gospel that they preach. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: we have this treasure in jars of clay

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his sufferings as if they are an experience of the death of Jesus. AT: "We are often in danger of dying, as Jesus died" (UDB) or "We always suffer in such a way that we experience the death of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: We always carry in our body the death of Jesus

contextId.information: Carrying the death of Jesus represents being in danger of dying because of being loyal to Jesus.  AT: "For those of us who are alive, God is always leading us to face death because we are joined to  Jesus" (UDB) or "People are always causing us who are alive to be in danger of dying because we are joined to Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: We who are alive are always carrying around in our body the death of Jesus

contextId.information: Paul speaks of thanksgiving as if it were an object that could become larger by itself. AT: "more and more people may give thanks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: thanksgiving may increase

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his sufferings and the glory that God will give him as if they were objects that can be weighed. The glory far outweighs the suffering. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: this momentary, light affliction is preparing us for an eternal weight of glory

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his physical body as if it were a temporary "earthly dwelling" and of the resurrection body that God will give as if it were a permanent "building" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if the earthly dwelling that we live in is destroyed, we have a building from God

contextId.information: The words "our heavenly dwelling" refer to the "building from God." Paul speaks of the resurrection body as if it were both a building and a piece of clothing that a person can put on. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: longing to be clothed with our heavenly dwelling

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the physical body as if it were a "tent." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: while we are in this tent

contextId.information: Paul refers to the difficulties that the physical body experiences as if they were heavy objects that are difficult to carry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: being burdened

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the body as if it were clothing. Here "to be unclothed" refers to the death of the physical body; "to be clothed" refers to having the resurrection body that God will give. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: We do not want to be unclothed ... we want to be clothed

contextId.information: Paul speaks of life as if it were an animal that eats "what is mortal." The physical body that will die will be replaced by a resurrection body that will live forever. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life

contextId.information: The Spirit is spoken of as if he was a partial downpayment toward eternal life. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2co:01:21|1:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who gave us the Spirit as a pledge of what is to come

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the physical body as if it were a place where a person dwells. AT: "while we are living in this earthly body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: while we are at home in the body

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the person who believes in Christ as if God had created a new person. AT: "he is a new person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he is a new creation

contextId.information: Paul speaks of anything that would prevent a person from trusting in Christ as if it were a physical object over which that person trips and falls. AT: "We do not want to do anything that will prevent people from believing our message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: We do not place a stumbling block in front of anyone

contextId.information: Paul speaks of their righteousness as if it is weapons that they use to fight spiritual battles. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: We have the armor of righteousness for the right hand and for the left

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his great affection for the Corinthians as having a heart that is open. AT: "we love you very much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: our heart is wide open

contextId.information: Paul addresses the Corinthians as his spiritual children. AT: "I speak as if I were your father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I speak as to children

contextId.information: Paul speaks of working together toward a common purpose as if it were two animals tied together to pull a plow or cart. AT: "team up with" or "have a close relationship with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: be tied together with

contextId.information: Paul refers to all Christians as forming a temple for God to dwell in. AT: "we are like a temple where the living God dwells" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
contextId.quote: we are the temple of the living God

contextId.information: This refers back to what Paul said in [[:en:bible:notes:2co:06:11|6:11-13]] about them opening their hearts to him. AT: "Make room for us in your hearts" or "Love us and accept us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Make room for us

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his and his associates' great love for the Corinthians as if they held them in their hearts. AT: "you are very dear to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you are in our hearts

contextId.information: Paul speaks of joy as if it is a liquid that fills him until he overflows. AT: "I am extremely joyful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I overflow with joy

contextId.information: This refers to God's presence. God's understanding and approval of Paul's truthfulness is referred to as God being able to see them. AT: "before God" or "with God as witness." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2co:04:01|4:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the sight of God

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the Corinthian believers as if they were producing physical goods. AT: "You do well in so many ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But you abound in everything

contextId.information: Paul speaks of Jesus before his incarnation as being rich, and of his becoming human as becoming poor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Even though he was rich, for your sakes he became poor

contextId.information: Paul uses the image of a farmer sowing seeds to describe the results of giving. As a farmer's harvest is based on how much he sows, so will God's blessings be little or much based on how generously the Corinthians give. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one who sows ... reap a blessing

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his trying to persuade the Corinthians to believe him and not the false teachers as if he were fighting a physical war. These words should be translated literally. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: we do not wage war ... we fight

contextId.information: Paul speaks of arguments as if they were a wall standing high against an army. The words "rises up" mean "stands tall," not that the "high thing" is floating up into the air. AT: "people use so they will not have to know who God is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: rises up against the knowledge of God

contextId.information: Paul speaks of helping the Corinthians to know Christ better as if he were constructing a building. AT: "to help you become better followers of Christ and not to discourage you so you stop following him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to build you up and not to destroy you

contextId.information: Paul is speaking of goodness as though it were something whose length people could measure. AT: "they look at each other and try to see who is better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they measure themselves by one another

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the authority he has as if it were a land over which he rules. AT: "and you are within the border of our authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: limits that reach as far as you

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his care for the Corinthian believers as if he had promised another man that he would prepare his daughter to marry him and he is most concerned that he be able to keep his promise to the man. AT: "I was like a father who promised to present his daughter to one husband. I promised to keep you as a pure virgin so I could give you to Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I promised you in marriage to one husband. I promised to present you as a pure virgin to Christ

contextId.information: Paul speaks of thoughts as if they were animals that people could lead along the wrong path. AT: "someone might cause you to believe lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your thoughts might be led astray away

contextId.information: Paul speaks of a false claim that his enemies state as if it were something that he can carry way. AT: "so that I might make it impossible" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in order that I may take away the claim

contextId.information: Paul speaks of rules that God did not make but some people force others to obey as if it were slavery. AT: "makes you follow rules they have thought of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: enslaves you

contextId.information: Paul knows that God will hold him responsible for how well the churches obey God and speaks of that knowledge as if it were a heavy object pushing him down. AT: "I know that God will hold me accountable for the spiritual growth of all the churches, and so I always feel like a heavy object is pushing me down" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: there is the daily pressure on me of my anxiety

contextId.information: Paul speaks of being angry about sin as if he had a fire inside his body. AT: "I am not angry" about the situation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I do not burn

contextId.information: Here Paul's physical problems are compared to a "thorn" piercing his "flesh." AT: affliction" or "a physical problem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a thorn in the flesh

contextId.information: Paul speaks of Christ's power as if it were a tent built over him. Possible meanings are 1) "people might see that I have the power of Christ" or 2) "I might truly have the power of Christ." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the power of Christ might reside on me

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his work and his physical life as if it were money that he or God could spend. AT: "I will gladly do any work and gladly allow God to permit people to kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will most gladly spend and be spent

contextId.information: "to strengthen you." Paul speaks of knowing how to obey God and desiring to obey him as if it were physical growth. AT: "so that you would know God and obey him better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for your strengthening

contextId.information: Paul speaks of helping the Corinthians to know Christ better as if he were constructing a building. AT: "to help you become better followers of Christ and not to discourage you so you stop following him." See how these words were translated in [[:en:bible:notes:1co:10:07|10:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that I may build you up, and not tear you down
